discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
We trust CUCM not the interent/customer/provider
C is correct, the CUCMs should be trusted

Selected Answer: A
A makes sense to me, you gotta trust the source IP of your incoming calls. This Cisco video states "if the source IP does not match an explicit entry in the configuration as a trusted VoIP source, the call is rejected"

https://video.cisco.com/detail/video/6050186898001

Selected Answer: C
I would go with C, and here is my reasoning:
If we are trusting the IP of the "Customer", then we are allowing the "Customer" to send whatever traffic/signalling to the CUBE (which can allow for Toll Fraud).

So , we do not trust "Customer" side but instead we trust the traffic/signalling from the System side (because the system is configured by Admins not Customers)

Selected Answer: C
C is correct, the CUCMs should be trusted

Selected Answer: C
CUCM to CUBE

Selected Answer: C
I'm going with C. This allows the CUBE to trust endpoints on the line side.

Unified CME 12.6 enforces security and toll fraud prevention for SIP line side on Unified CME. The ip address trusted authentication configuration blocks unauthorized calls from the line side. Hence, the Toll fraud Prevention feature secures Unified CME 12.6 and later from unauthorized users on the line side. As part of the configuration for toll fraud prevention on Unified CME 12.6, all the line side endpoints must register to Unified CME.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucme/admin/configuration/manual/cmeadm/cmetoll.html

It should depends what is the call direction (inbound or outbound):
"The CLI command ip address trusted list lists the IP address of INCOMING calls from all the registered directory numbers. The command is configured under voice service voip configuration mode."
So A, or C or Both

Selected Answer: C
Trusts list are who the CUBE trusts, the CUCM is .11 so we must trust .11
Answer should be A

discussion.content:
Can someone help me on this one?

Should be A? Allow SIP to H323?

Selected Answer: B
B is outgoing to CUCM
D is incoming, but we need the translation profile under the dial-peer 11

comments.content: Adding the dial-peer 11 is pointing to Provider/Customer. Dial-peer 10 is pointing to CUCM but is missing incoiming/outgoing matching and needs something to be in the call routing,

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B, although the call still wouldn't work even with it added.

Dial-peer 11 is the inbound dial-peer in this case. It's already being matched by the "incoming called-number ." line. Translation-profiles are applied AFTER matching the inbound dial-peer, if the dial-peer has the "translation-profile incoming profile1" line, which is actually missing in this case and none of the available answers have that, so the translation-profile that was created in the first figure is actually completely useless in this question.

What needs to be done is the add the "translation-profile incoming profile1" line to dial-peer 11 AND add the "destination-pattern 5555 (or 5555$)" to dial-peer 10 to make it match that as the outbound dial-peer. Currently, there is nothing matching it as the outbound dial-peer. That second piece would be answer B.
I think answer is C

comments.content: Ingress has a catch all (.).. Egress needs to match a destination patterm

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. To allow the last four digits of a dialed number to be sent from the Cisco Unified Border Element (CUBE) to Cisco Unified Communications Manager (CUCM), the engineer must configure an additional dial peer on the CUBE with the incoming called-number command. This command specifies the incoming called number for a dial peer and is used to associate an incoming call leg with a specific dial peer. The configuration would be as follows:

CUBE(config)# dial-peer voice 11 voip
CUBE(config-dial-peer)# incoming called-number 5555
This configuration will allow the CUBE to send only the last four digits of the dialed number (in this case, 5555) to the CUCM

comments.content:
It's not D. Dial-peer 11 is the inbound dial-peer in this case. It's already being matched by the "incoming called-number ." line. Translation-profiles are applied AFTER matching the inbound dial-peer, if the dial-peer has the "translation-profile incoming profile1" line, which is actually missing in this case and none of the available answers have that, so the translation-profile that was created in the first figure is actually completely useless in this question.

What needs to be done is the add the "translation-profile incoming profile1" line to dial-peer 11 AND add the "destination-pattern 5555 (or 5555$)" to dial-peer 10 to make it match that as the outbound dial-peer. Currently, there is nothing matching it as the outbound dial-peer. That second piece would be answer B. It still wouldn't work with that, but it is required as one of two necessary configurations.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
it's D for me

questions.question_text: Where would an administrator update learned patterns from the DNA UI?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
first go to Cisco Unified Serviceability in CUCM. Then navigate Tools --> Dialed Number analizer ( or simply go to https://<cucm IP or fqdn>/dna/showHome.do )
Finally, navigate Service --> Control Center.
To add/remove/update learned patterns, from the DNA UI, select Service > Control Center

choices.C: Reset the dial peer on CUBE_1.
choices.B: Deploy a voice class to CUBE_2.

discussion.content: I think the more correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: B
D. is incorrect. I does not matter you configure all the codecs in a transcoder profile if you are negotiating just one codec in the dial-peer in CUBE 1.
B. is correct, since with a voice class you are allowing to negotiate the codec asked, independently if there are or not transcoder profiles in the CUBE 2.

comments.content: in the signalig, but cubes must accord to use g.729r8. If one or the another CUBE does have transcoders configured or not, these is another stuff.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
CUBE_1 (codec g729r8) // CUBE_2 (codec g729br8) // Question (must use the g729r8)
 Transcoder on CUBE_1 > Will not use g729r8 it will change to g729br8
 Solution: voice class to CUBE_2
my answer is B

Selected Answer: D
I believe these two codec are not interoperable so I'll vote the answer with transcoder.

Selected Answer: B
I vote B. The requirement is for both CUBE1 and 2 to use G.729r8. A transcoder would make calls work of course, but that doesn't satisfy the requirement. The only way to do that would be to deploy a voice class to CUBE2 to explicitly add G.729r8.
As voice class option on CUBE1 is not an option my answer is D

comments.content:
I read again.
CUBE1 does not need Transcoder because it is using g729r8.
I changed my answer to B.
Deploying a voice -class on CUBE2 adding required coded

Such requirement is needed to be set up. And B seems to point that.

CUBE_2 (config)# Voice class codec 11
 codec preference 1 g729r8
 codec preference 2 g729br8

CUBE_2 (config)# dial-peer voice 11 voip
 voice-class codec 11
 no codec g729br8

discussion.content:
It looks like such requirement is needed. And B seems to point that.

CUBE_2 (config)# 
 codec preference 1 g729r8
 codec preference 2 g729br8

CUBE_2 (config)#
dial-peer voice 11 voip
 voice-class codec 10
 no codec g729br8

D is correct. 

G.729r8 is already configured in C1. 

A transcoder in any of the CUBEs would do. Same as a voice class.

I am selecting D

Question states that the call must use G.729r8, which means CUBE_2 needs to be able to "speak" G.729r8, instead of G.729br8 currently configured. The first step towards CUBE_2 supporting G.729r8 is configuring a voice class with G.729r8 as one of the options. Hence I am going with Answer B.

A codec voice class is a construct within which a codec preference order can be defined. A codec voice class can then be applied to a dial peer, which then follows the preference order defined in the codec voice class. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/voice/cube/configuration/cube-book/voi-negt-aud-code.html
Answer is B. Both must use G729br8, Voice class permits to negotiate a list of supported codecs.

comments.content: this will be true if they have multiple codecs to negotiate, if Cube 1 has A and Cube 1 has B - there is nothing in common so how they will be able to negotiate. I will go with D
Even though you configure 1000 transcoder profiles, you always will be negotiating the one codec configured in your dial peer.
Cube 1 has A and Cube 2 has B - nothing in common *
If you look carefully and CLI you will see that both codecs are configured on CUBE_1
Why necessarily? with transcoder even G729r8 can be used just that transcoder is set on Cube A side. What do you mean to modify Cube 2 ?
the only thing related to Cube 2 here in answers is to deploy voice class - which has no much to do with requirement

Think of it this way.. If you configure a Codec voice-class on CUBE02, the voice-class could include the codec of CUBE01 in its preference list, which will allow it to negotiate based on the codec of CUBE01.

Configuring a transcoder on Cube 1indicates that you want to add the G729br8 codec right? This would certainly allow for the call to establish as a G729br8 setup, but the question explicitly states this call must setup as a G729r8. Only way yo do that would be to modify the Cube 2 config.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I vote C. In all the examples I've seen for using this command the excluded IP range is lowest --> highest when added as a command. In other words, lowest IP then highest IP is the correct format.

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure a DHCP server to save automatic bindings on a remote host that has an IP address of 172.16.1 1. The IP address range of 172.16.1.103 to 172.16.1.106 must be blocked from the DHCP server. Which set of commands must the engineer run?
